title: Synthetic Recap
body:
INDIANAPOLIS — The final score read 106-85, a convincing victory for the Indiana Pacers over the visiting Vancouver Grizzlies. But the numbers that truly mattered, the ones that will echo through the annals of the franchise, belonged to one man: Reggie Miller.

On this night in 1998, Miller didn't just play basketball; he authored a masterpiece, pouring in a staggering 42 points in a virtuoso shooting performance that left the Grizzlies defense grasping at air. The Pacers’ sharpshooter was the entire narrative, a force of nature who single-handedly decided the contest long before the final buzzer.

The game was a clinic. Miller’s points didn't come from volume alone; they came with ruthless efficiency. He was a flurry of motion, running defenders off screens and launching from distances that seemed to defy logic. Each swish of the net was a dagger, each three-pointer a demoralizing blow that chipped away at Vancouver’s resolve. The Grizzlies, led by Blue Edwards' 17 points, simply had no answer for the incendiary onslaught.

While the Pacers' victory was a comprehensive team effort, with Rik Smits adding a solid 16 points, the night belonged unequivocally to their star. Miller’s 42-point eruption was more than just a high-scoring game; it was a historic individual achievement, a testament to his legendary status as one of the game's most feared scorers. In a league of giants, it was the assassin from the perimeter who delivered a performance for the ages, reminding everyone in attendance that on any given night, one man can become the entire story.
